meta.hint: Some words are alike. They go together in a group. eg. Red, Green, and blue go together in the colors group.
meta.question: Find the odd one out  from the group of words.

meta.hint:
An adjective is a word that tells you about a person, place, animal or thing.
Some adjectives tell you how many.
eg. Kim sees two trees. I have three dogs.
meta.question: Complete the sentence  using number words to match the picture.

meta.hint:
A noun names a person, animal, place, or, thing.
Some nouns name a person. eg. girl, boy.
Some nouns name an animal. eg. duck, cat.
Some nouns name a place. eg. park, school.
Some nouns name a thing. eg. hat, train
meta.question: Complete the sentence to match the picture.

meta.hint:
A pronoun is a word that takes the place of a noun or nouns. Use 'he' and 'him' for one boy or man. John is here. eg. He sees you. eg. You see him.
Use 'she' and 'her' for one girl or woman. Kate is here. eg. She sees you. eg. You see her.
Use 'it' for one thing. There is a rabbit here. eg. It sees you. eg. You see it.
Use 'we' and 'us' for more than one person, with I or me. John and I are here. eg. We see you. eg. You see us.
Use 'they' and 'them' for more than one person or thing. John and Kate are here. eg. They see you. eg. You see them.
meta.question: Select the correct Possessive Pronoun.

meta.hint:
A common noun names a type of person, animal, place or thing. A common noun starts with a lowercase letter, unless it is the first word in a sentence. Example - cat, girl, park
A proper noun is a special name for one person, animal, place or thing. A proper noun always starts with a capital letter. Example - Max, Jane, Jackson Park Max is the name of one cat. Jane is the name of one girl. Jackson Park is the name of one park.
meta.question: Select the proper noun.
Select the possessive noun.
meta.hint:
Possessive Nouns show belonging or owning. Add -'s to make a noun a Possessive noun.
eg. That was Tom's project.

meta.question: Identify whether the given sentence is a statement, a question, a command or an exclamation.
meta.hint:
A noun names a person, animal, place, or, thing.
Some nouns name a person. Example - girl, boy.
Some nouns name an animal. Example - duck, cat.
Some nouns name a place. Example - park, school.
Some nouns name a thing. Example - hat, train
meta.meta_question: Complete the sentence to match the picture.

meta.question: Find and select the complete sentence.
meta.hint:
A sentence has a naming part and an action part. It shows complete thought.
eg. My sister got very good marks. eg. I do exercise every morning.
A sentence starts with a capital letter. It ends with a full stop (.) or another end mark.

blocks.name: Naming part or Action part of the sentence?

meta.hint:
Every sentence has a naming part and an action part.
The naming part tells who or what the sentence is about. eg. That building is so tall. eg. Rocky is sad.
The action part tells something about the naming part. The action part can tell what the naming part does. It can also tell what the naming part is like. eg. That building is so tall. eg. Rocky is sad.
meta.question: Identify whether the part of sentence is action part or naming part?
Complete the sentence with the best question word?
meta.hint:
Use who to ask about a person. eg. Who saw the bird first?
Use what to ask about a thing. eg. What do birds eat?
Use when to ask about a time. eg. When do birds sleep?
Use where to ask about a place. eg. Where is the bird's nest?
Use why to ask for a reason. eg. Why do birds sing?

blocks.name: Who, What, When, Why or Where?

meta.question: Type the spelling of the word.
Type the spelling of the word.
